awd_titl_txt: CCI Phase I: NSF Center for Chemo-Mechanical Assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Much as a river current carries a pebble, fluid flows can carry particulates such as nanoparticles and microcapsules. While mechanical pumps are conventionally used to drive fluid flow, chemical "pumps" can also propel fluid by using chemical reaction networks to create gradients in chemical concentrations and fluid densities. Researchers in the NSF Center for Chemo-Mechanical Assembly (CCMA) are creating new transformative tools to enable unprecedented control over fluid flow and particle organization in confined environments. These precisely controlled fluid flows enable the design of self-powered, self-sustaining systems that organize particles and are capable of performing complex functions such as an autonomous nanoparticle system that detects a chemical source and collectively delivers a response chemical to it resulting in a vital analysis or creation of a novel structure. The CCMA team includes expertise in catalysis, synthetic chemistry, physical chemistry, fluid flow, and modeling. In addition to providing the chemistry community with new chemical reaction network tools, CCMA is also contributing to science and technology workforce development by training students in multidisciplinary experimental and modeling techniques. Through its industry affiliates program, CCMA is engaging industry in student training and technology transfer. Concurrent with the research, the team is launching a vigorous program of education and outreach to the public. This includes expanding undergraduate and graduate research opportunities for underrepresented groups in research-based careers. The team is also participating in several large-scale public outreach programs including public lectures, designing hands-on traveling exhibits, and teaming with museums and science centers. 

Through collaborative research that combines innovative modeling and experimental studies, the NSF CCI Phase I: Center for Chemo-Mechanical Assembly (CCMA) is harnessing catalytic chemical reactions to introduce spatiotemporal chemical gradients that drive the flow of a surrounding fluid. This flow, in turn, enables the manipulation of the collective behavior of suspended particles to drive new modes of dynamic self-organization. The Center is developing novel approaches to cause directed transport of nano- and micron-scale materials, control particle organization in confined chambers, and establish new chemical routes for regulating non-equilibrium structure formation from particles in solution. These studies are providing the chemistry community with fundamentally new tools and knowledge, including new chemistries for the creation of catalytic cascades; determination of design rules for chemical feedback loops; demonstration of new modes of out-of-equilibrium assembly; and progress toward new understanding of the nonlinear behavior and auto-amplification emerging from these systems. Potential applications include the creation of standalone microfluidic devices that autonomously perform multi-stage chemical reactions and assays for portable biomedical applications; automated materials assembly in harsh environments; and small-scale factories that can operate autonomously to build microscale components for use in fine instrumentation and robotic systems, and, in parallel, to screen for optimal reaction parameters yielding micro-machines with specified properties. To generate excitement and public appreciation about this emerging area of chemistry, the CCMA team is participating in several large-scale public outreach programs at the participating institutions, including public lectures, hands-on traveling exhibits, and museum and science center projects.

por.por_cntn:
The research objective of the Phase I Center for Chemo-mechanical Assembly (CCMA) was to design catalytic reactions in solution that ?pump? the surrounding fluid and permit unprecedented control over the spatial and temporal behavior of the resultant flows. These ?patterned? flows in turn propel the self-organization of dispersed nano- and microscopic objects and provide new chemical routes to regulate non-equilibrium behavior in solution. The work is poised to have a transformative impact because our designs let chemistry do the work by generating programmable flow fields that enable chemically driven forms of self-powered assembly. To realize this concept, the Phase I CCMA team harnessed chemistry as the essential, key element to promote self-driven dynamic assembly.  

In Phase I, we demonstrated that reactions promoted by surface-anchored enzymes can pump fluids with a directionality and speed that is dictated by the choice of enzymes. Control of these processes hinged on understanding how chemical densities and concentration gradients produce the desired flow behavior, which lead to controllable self-organization over objects ranging from nanoscale solid particles to macroscale deformable sheets. Advances in Phase I led to the publication of 24 peer-reviewed papers.  

Intellectual Merit.

The CCMA's vision to replace mechanical pumps with chemical processes has far-reaching technological implications. Namely, we designed integrated systems, which combine chemical processes, modes of chemo-mechanical transduction, and chemo-responsive materials, in order to: 1) minimize waste and enhance sustainability, since the integrated systems will evolve in function and purpose rather than being single-use; 2) optimize performance by continuous structural refinement (e.g., as the self-forming fluidic circuits); and 3) accomplish tasks collectively and emergently in ways not possible with a single constituent (e.g., the cooperative interactive elastic sheets). Such self-powered systems can sense and respond to their environment, through the responsive chemistry designed into surfaces, and will be inherently mobile, since they are untethered to power sources or specific locations. The distinctive attributes of our integrated chemical systems, embedded in reconfigurable flexible substrates, make them ideal for future applications and hence, allow us to meet the important goal of extending the reach of our scientific findings well beyond the academic community. 

Broader Impact

The CCMA fostered exchanges of students and postdocs among the four research groups in order to enhance their training and facilitate Center-wide collaboration.  The exchanges took the form of both in-person visits to other labs and regular teleconference discussions. The in-person visits gave experimentalists access to vital equipment not available at their home institution and hence, enhanced their research training. For example, Cristiam Santa Chalarca, a graduate student with Emrick (who received his Ph.D. in 2018), performed synthetic polymer chemistry that bridged the theoretical work of Balazs and the enzymatic and physical chemistry associated with diffusiophoretic motion studied by Sen and Stone. Cristiam's visit to the Stone lab at Princeton allowed him to perform important rheological measurements that solidified our understanding of the relationship between polymer zwitterion structure and droplet-droplet interactions and initiated several new studies. The training that Cristiam received in turn helped him mentor a new CCMA-supported Ph.D. student, Marcel Brown, in Emrick's laboratory. Both Santa Chalarca and Brown mentored high school interns (from Frontier Regional School in Deerfield, MA) offering a unique laboratory experience in the chemistry of supracolloidal fibers and materials with robust, stable structures. Stone served as the outside member of Brown's PhD Committee.

            The exchanges also included weekly teleconferences between the Balazs and Sen groups allowing the experimentalists to provide valuable data to the modelers, and the modelers to suggest new studies for the experimentalists. Balazs and her postdocs visited Penn State twice in 2018 to meet with the Sen group to map the progress of their joint theoretical and experimental work. The close collaboration led to fundamental insights into the design of self-organizing and bifurcating fluids,. The findings also provided guidelines to facilitate further automation of microfluidic devices. In a parallel collaboration, the Balazs and Sen groups engaged in in-depth studies of photothermal pumping of fluids and particle assembly. The Sen and Stone groups worked closely to build on their discovery of a catalytic, silver-based fluidic pump that can detect pH changes. Oleg Shklyaev, a postdoc with Balazs, met frequently with Bhargav Rallabandi from the Stone group for model development of complex systems. In June 2018, Emrick visited the Balazs lab to discuss their collaboration on creating active sheets and Stone worked with Balazs and colleagues during a 2019 visit to Pittsburgh designed to bridge theory and simulations. These numerous cross-institutional, inter-group interactions, involving experimentalists, simulators and theorists/modelers, broadened and enhanced the scientific toolbox and intuition of the researchers, which will enable new innovations in future research.
